newsitem.title: UK: BAe down, analysts play down aircraft report.
newsitem.headline: BAe down, analysts play down aircraft report.

text.p: Shares in British Aerospace Plc dropped on Tuesday though analysts played down the significance of a report that it risked losing its role in building a planned European military transport aircraft.

"Shares are looking a little weak across the sector, there is not much volume in any of them and I don't think there is any particular significance for BAe shares in the report on the large transport aircraft," said Zafar Khan, analyst at SocGen.
"It is just a paper plane," said Brian Newman at Henderson Crosthwaite. The stock was down 16p or 1.3 percent at 12.37-1/2 stg by 0923 GMT.

Citing a report in Flight magazine, the Financial Times said the Royal Air Force wants to halve the number of the transport aircraft it buys, taking Britain below 20 percent of orders and making the UK's share too small to keep wing manufacture.

Yet Khan said there were other more significant stories that had hurt the stock in recent sessions -- reports that Saudi Arabia could buy U.S. F16 fighters and the grounding of older versions of its Hawk training jet.
Dealers pointed out that BAe had been among the top performing FTSE 100 stocks in 1996 and could be due some profit-taking. It reached a record 13.00 stg on January 20.
